EXTRACTED VALUE: This one's a brilliant weekend rental, just like the movies.
Burnout Revenge for 360 is a fantastic experience, capturing the essence of the series better than any of its predecessors. [Apr 2006, p.81]
Technical problems are abundant, the character development is mostly irrelevant and the adventure is linear.
There’s nothing revolutionary in Eternal Sonata, but it’s a well-executed RPG with style in abundance. [Nov 2007, p.98]
Another game that really has a lot of potential but ultimately comes out to be disappointing.
Check it out if you are interested in the RPG genre at all.
At times challenging, and at others simply frustrating, you’ll need keen wits and grace under fire to deal with the obstacles presented in this title.
Perfectly tuned to the 360 controller, it's killer racing action for newbie and veteran alike. [Dec 2007, p.123]
Poor mini-games mixed with horrible controls and the worst 'host' ever - the best way to describe Fuzion Frenzy 2. [Issue 18, p.95]
The whole thing feels like a massive missed opportunity. [Issue #10]
Expensive at half the price, this is boring for Lost fans and baffling for the rest. [May 2008, p.72]
Very much its own game, Skate is a great start to what should be a stellar series. [Dec 2007, p.62]
It is a game that utterly fails to capture any of the elements that make its source material so enduring and beloved.
And 2K7: time to innovate. More is not better at this point. [Oct. 2006, p.106]
Tight, fun and fast-paced racing action that just about anyone can enjoy. [Nov 2008, p.89]
Enemy Territory: Quake Wars is a port from the earlier released PC version, and not a very good port at that.
Scant little more than a badly reared puppy that’s bound for the pound.
The single-player campaign in GRID is definitely worth a test drive. Multiplayer has its moments, but you could skip over it without missing much.
It’s loaded with extras and great touches that push it over the edge of greatness, so much so that the bland graphics are quickly forgotten.
Do you like Guitar Hero and Aerosmith? This is the game for your. But everyone else? Give it a miss. [Sept 2008, p.78]
UT3's Xbox 360 version is huffing and puffing and bringing up the rear, long after anyone cares to watch the race.
For a game that promised so much, Viking really doesn't do much in the way of delivering.
A title that's running on autopilot. It looks better than the previous Ace Combat offerings, but little else has changed.
The controls are handled nicely enough and the tracks are designed well enough. Too bad the Career mode is over a bit too quickly.
Brilliant.
A nearly perfect experience for a very select crowd. It might even be convincing enough to convert a few non-believers, but it's not perfect.
The Club provides some old-school single-player thrills, but it fails to live up to its initial promise.
I was not totally disappointed with Fight Night Round 3, but I did walk away feeling like something was missing.
The game is obviously geared most toward the younger set, but even kids like a bit of challenge, right?
Full Auto is a neat idea, but unfortunately it's just one neat idea, stretched across the entire game. And that wears thin pretty quickly.
Flawed, dull and not much to look at, Bullet Witch is an exercise in tedium that own't enrich your life at all. [Issue 18, p.96]
After the shambles that is "Reservoir Dogs," The Godfather shows how to bring a film license to the world of video games.
I’ll admit I was hooked for the first five hours, but as the game waned on, so did the entertainment of the game.
Agent 47 makes his debut on the 360, with a crafty action game that manages to blend all the different genre elements into one solid offering.
Yes, there were great additions to this year, but the horrible AI, and multiplayer just really mess up the experience for me.
The online mode is very bare bones – there are rankings, but that’s about it.
Playing Madden NFL 07 on Xbox 360 is like playing "Madden NFL 2002" with next-gen graphics. The drive falls well short of a touchdown, even now!
Halo 3 gives a deeper, smoother and grander ride then ever before.
Tedious puzzles and repetitious level design makes Overlord become very predictable all too quickly. [July 2007, p.90]
One of the most easily accessible games on the Xbox 360.
It still dosen't match up to Pro Evolution Soccer, but it has improved and become more refined and innovative.
While it isn't a revolution in racing design, it's a good game with a lot to do.
Right out of the gate, Spider-Man 3 is going to smack you in the face with some of the worst next-gen graphics you have ever seen.
For a next-gen price tag you expect to get a next-gen product, and sadly MotoGP '06 hasn't quite made a successful leap to the next-generation.
Perfectly rendered cutscenes play out like extravagant soap operas with more over-the-top personalities than an episode of America’s Next Top Model.
Shadowrun is a decent multiplayer with a great idea that needed some more time to be fully utilised.
Ninety-Nine Nights puts a lot of enemies onscreen but doesn't give you many interesting ways to dispose of them.
It’s not that Burst Limit is a bad game, it’s just painfully average. [Issue#34, p.96]
